overview: Employers' responsibilities for different contract types: full-time, part-time, fixed term, agency workers, consultants, zero hours, family members, volunteers and young workers
title: Contract types and employer responsibilities

table.body:
As an employer, the tax and employment responsibilities you have for your staff will depend on the type of contract you give them and their [employment status.](/employment-status "Employment status")

Contract types include:

- [full-time and part-time contracts](/contract-types-and-employer-responsibilities/fulltime-and-parttime-contracts "Full-time and part-time contracts")
- [fixed-term contracts](/contract-types-and-employer-responsibilities/fixedterm-contracts "Fixed-term contracts")
- [agency staff](/contract-types-and-employer-responsibilities/agency-staff "Agency staff")
- [freelancers, consultants, contractors](/contract-types-and-employer-responsibilities/freelancers-consultants-and-contractors "Freelancers, consultants and contractors")
- [zero hour contracts](/contract-types-and-employer-responsibilities/zero-hour-contracts "Zero hour contracts")

There are also special rules for employing [family members, young people and volunteers.](/contract-types-and-employer-responsibilities/employing-family-young-people-and-volunteers "Employing family, young people and volunteers")
table.title: Overview

table.body:
As an employer you must give employees: 

* a written statement of employment or [contract](/employment-contracts-and-conditions/overview "Employment contracts")
* the statutory minimum level of paid holiday
* a payslip showing all deductions, eg [National Insurance contributions (NICs)](/national-insurance-contributions-nics-for-employers/overview "National Insurance contributions for your employees")
* the statutory minimum length of rest breaks
* Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)
* maternity, paternity and adoption pay and leave

You must also:

* make sure employees don't work longer than the maximum allowed
* pay employees at least the minimum wage
* have employer’s liability insurance
* provide a safe and secure working environment
* [register with HM Revenue and Customs](/register-as-an-employer-for-tax/overview "Register as an employer for tax") to deal with payroll, tax and NICs
* consider flexible working requests
* [avoid discrimination](/employer-preventing-discrimination/what-discrimination-is "Employers: preventing discrimination") in the workplace
* make [reasonable adjustments](/reasonable-adjustments-for-disabled-workers "Reasonable adjustments for disabled workers") to your business premises if your employee is disabled

*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: Full-time and part-time contracts

table.body:
Fixed-term contracts:

* last for a certain length of time
* are set in advance
* end when a specific task is completed
* end when a specific event takes place

Fixed-term employees must receive the same treatment as full-time permanent staff. This includes the same:  

* pay and conditions
* opportunity to apply for permanent jobs in the business
* employment rights
* tax obligations

They must also have the same or equal benefits packages or pensions schemes.

Any employee on a fixed-term contract for 4 or more years will automatically become a permanent employee when their contract is renewed or they are given a new contract. 

However, an employer and unions (or a staff association) may make a collective agreement that removes the automatic right to become a permanent employee in these circumstances.
table.title: Fixed-term contracts

table.body:
As an employer, you can hire temporary staff through [agencies](/using-an-employment-agency-employers-rights "Using an employment agency: employers' rights"). This means:

* you pay the agency, including the employee's National Insurance contributions (NICs) and Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)
* it's the agency’s responsibility to make sure workers get their rights under working time regulations 
* you must make sure they can access your facilities (such as canteen and childcare facilities), and information on your job vacancies
* after 12 weeks continuous employment in the same role, agency workers get the same terms and conditions as permanent employees, including pay, working time, rest periods, night work, breaks, annual leave and maternity, paternity or adoption leave 
* you must provide the agency with information about the relevant terms and conditions in your business so that they can ensure the worker gets equal treatment after 12 weeks in the same job
* you must allow agency workers to use any shared facilities (eg a staff cateen or childcare) and give them information about job vacancies from the first day they work there
* you are still responsible for their [health and safety](/health-safety-at-work/employers-responsibilities "Health and safety at work: employers' responsibilities")


*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: Agency staff

table.body:
If you hire a freelancer, consultant or contractor it means that:

* they are self-employed or are part of other companies
* they often look after their own tax and National Insurance contributions (NICs)
* they might not be entitled to the same rights as workers, eg minimum wage
* you're still responsible for their [health and safety](/health-safety-at-work/employers-responsibilities "Health and safety at work: employers' responsibilities")

*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
table.title: Freelancers, consultants and contractors

table.body:
Zero hour contracts are usually for 'piece work' or 'on call' work, eg interpreters.

This means:

* they are on call to work when you need them
* you don’t have to give them work
* they don’t have to do work when asked

You are still responsible for [health and safety](/health-safety-at-work/employers-responsibilities "Health and safety at work: employers' responsibilities") of staff on zero hour contracts.
table.title: Zero hour contracts

table.body:
##Family

If you hire family members you must:

* avoid special treatment in terms of pay, promotion and working conditions
* make sure tax and National Insurance contributions (NICs) are still paid
* follow working time regulations for [younger family members](/child-employment "Child employment")
* have employer’s liability insurance that covers any young family members

##Volunteers and voluntary staff

When taking on volunteers or voluntary staff you:

* are responsible for their [health and safety](/health-safety-at-work "Health and safety at work: employers' responsibilities")
* must give inductions and training in the tasks they're going to do

##Young people

You can employ young people if they are 13 or over but there are [special rules](/child-employment "Child employment") about how long they can work and what jobs they can do. Once someone is 18 they're classed as an 'adult worker' and different rules apply. 

As well as following these [rules](/child-employment "Child employment") you must do a risk assessment before taking on young workers.

Young people may also have certain employment rights like:

* statutory maternity pay and ordinary statutory paternity pay if they qualify as a result of their [continuous employment](/continuous-employment-what-it-is "Continuous employment")
* paid time off for study and training
* redundancy pay

Young workers and apprentices have different rates from adult workers for the [National Minimum Wage](/national-minimum-wage-rates "National Minimum Wage rates").

*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
table.title: Employing family, young people and volunteers
